results.title: Minute movie masterpieces: 30 film classics in 30 minutes
results.creator_credit: Cliff Notes, Richard Foos and Rhino Video
results.brief_description: This compilation video gives a quick synopsis of 30 classic movies ranging from “Birth of a nation” to “A Star is born”. It uses key clips and highlights from each film and a whirlwind narration from speed readers to deliver maximum plot content in the one minute available, before moving on to the next title. Written and edited by David Starns.

results.title: Minoru: memory of exile
results.creator_credit: Michael Fukushima, Bill Pettigrew and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: With the bombing of the American naval base at Pearl Habour on December 7, 1941, the position of Japanese Canadians was altered dramatically. This is the story of one among the thousands of Japanese families that were affected by a growing atmosphere of racism and rejection that saw Japanese Canadians dispatched to internment camps in the mountains of British Columbia and following the end of the war, given the choice to be deported to Japan, whether it was their birth place or otherwise, or be placed in working groups throughout Canada. Directed by Michael Fukushima, this is a short documentary film interspersed with classical animation and archival material about his father, Minoru, and his experiences, first as a nine year old, of their family’s loss of property, their transferral to internment camps and then attempted resettlement in Japan. With its sensitive reflection on memory and survival and his own relationship with his father, Fukushima’s work continues the study until the Canadian government’s official apology and compensation for loss and suffering in the 1980s and interrogates his own sense of being a Canadian after this time.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Fukushima, Bill Pettigrew and ONF | NFB

results.title: Mining in Australia: the the story of copper
results.creator_credit: Brian Merrett and Tasmanian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes copper mining at Mt Lyell in Tasmania. Shows blasting, crushing of the ore, removal of iron particles, grinding the ore to powder, silo stores, blast furnace, removal of slag, the converter, and finally the cathode copper.

results.title: Mining for copper
results.creator_credit: Gaumont-British Instructional and J. Arthur Rank
results.brief_description: An account of mining and refining of copper in Northern Rhodesia; the geography of the country; details of structure of the mines; operation of the mine; processes for the extraction of copper from ore including the crushing, smelting, refining and final casting into commercial moulds for shipment.

results.title: Mining employment opportunities
results.creator_credit: Keith Gow, Don Harley and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A record of a visit by seven Aboriginal community leaders from the Northern Territory, to three mining centres, Mount Isa, Mary Kathleen and Bougainville Copper. This enabled them to see how a mining operation works and what kinds of jobs exist in the mines.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Gow, Don Harley and Film Australia

results.title: Mining centre: Johannesburg
results.creator_credit: Donald Swanson, S.G. Fergusson and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: A survey of the mining city of Johannesburg and a short explanation on the nature of gold bearing reefs. A map of Africa shows the mineral areas and an animated diagram of the Witwatersrand explains how the gold reefs lie. The development of the Rand and of Johannesburg is outlined in brief historic sequences and its relation to the growth of mining explained.

results.title: Miners of Bolivia
results.creator_credit: Films Incorporated and Institut für Film und Bild
results.brief_description: A study of the work and submarginal living of tin-ore miners of Altiplano is presented against a background of the natural beauty of Bolivia. Shows effect of the terrain and climate on the Indians’ lives, and surveys the problems that have contributed to poverty in certain areas of the country.

results.title: Mineral wealth: North West Australia
results.creator_credit: Frederic Fisher and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: The latent wealth in mineral deposits in north-west Western Australia is being exploited nowadays by large commercial combines, assisted by the Department of Mines. Modern drilling rigs, mining camps and mobile laboratories are used in the work to extract iron, copper, tin, blue asbestos, white asbestos, manganese, tantalite and other minerals.

results.title: Mineral wealth
results.brief_description: Survey of mineral wealth in Australia today. Raw materials mined, refined and processed in Australia include silver, lead, zinc, copper, iron ore, bauxite, uranium and coal. Shows typical mining towns, Broken Hill, Mt Isa, Mary Kathleen, Rum Jungle, Weipa, Yampi Sound and in the Latrobe Valley; and production and refining centres - Port Kembla, Cocklecreek and Bell Bay.

results.title: Mineral sands of Eastern Australia
results.creator_credit: Associated Minerals Consolidated and Cinesound Movietone
results.brief_description: A survey of mineral sand mining on the beaches of Northern NSW and Queensland. Shows the whole process from drilling, analysing, mining and processing the sand for export overseas. The sand produces such minerals as rutile, titanium and zirion - all of which are used in industry. Also shows the rehabilitation of the areas by the company after the mining operation.
